{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3731357,"name":"Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor","username":"YuvalGur-2231","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/df788c/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-04T22:42:48.182Z","cooked":"

Hey there,

Over the past few years, we‚Äôve experimented with many different types of LED strips. We started with the standard WS2812 strips, which are specifically programmable via the roboRIO FPGA and WPILib. In particular, we used the 144 LEDs/m IP65 version ‚Äî cheap and super reliable.

The main drawback was the 5V supply requirement. We powered them either through the roboRIO PWM (6V/2A) or the VRM 5V/2A port, but that severely limited the strip length: ~20 mA per LED meant we could only run about 100 LEDs (~1 meter) before we started noticing voltage drop and dimming at the far end.

To address this, we switched to WS2815 strips. They include a backup data line (which we shorted to the default data pin), but more importantly, they run on 12V, which allowed us to extend the length since the current could now exceed 2A without major issues.

At Worlds, however, we noticed that 254 (and a few other teams) were running what looked like a continuous strip ‚Äî with no visible LED separation. We tried buying a cheap WS2811 strip that looked similar, but while it was denser, it definitely wasn‚Äôt continuous.

Do you happen to know what the exact ‚Äúcontinuous strip‚Äù type is? And if so, do you have a recommendation for a cheap and reliable version we could use?

Thanks a lot for your help!
‚Äì Yuval

YuvalGur-2231:

5V supply requirement

I don‚Äôt know about the LEDs to which you refer but my team uses an old 12vdc to 5vdc converter from years ago and other similar new converters - there are hundreds of them available. The VRM is unnecessarily fancy and limiting as you note for our LED usage.

The ‚Äúcontinuous‚Äù strip you‚Äôre seeing on some of these bots is almost certainly just a regular strip with a diffuser in front of it - i.e. a thin piece of matte white or frosted clear polycarb.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-05T01:29:49.303Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":56.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505977,"topic_slug":"recommendations-for-reliable-and-affordable-led-strips","display_username":"Zach Hoegberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/recommendations-for-reliable-and-affordable-led-strips/505977/3","custom_user_title":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3731460,"name":"Roger Moore","username":"orangemoore","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-05T01:39:37.408Z","cooked":"

I don‚Äôt think it is. You can see how the diffusion layer looks to be incorporated into the led strip in 254‚Äôs robot photo here

WCP sells CoB (chip-on-board) LED Strips here which I think is what they‚Äôre looking for.

And RC briefly mentions them 1323 - 2025 Tech Binder - #172 by R.C in this post.

I haven‚Äôt used these personally but we‚Äôre looking into them for next year.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-05T01:39:37.408Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":35.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505977,"topic_slug":"recommendations-for-reliable-and-affordable-led-strips","display_username":"Roger Moore","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://wcproducts.com/products/wcp-sensors","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"WCP Sensors ‚Äì WestCoast Products","clicks":20},{"url":"https://media.team254.com/2025/03/948e07b9-2025-robot-full.png","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"948e07b9-2025-robot-full.png","clicks":15},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/1323-2025-tech-binder/500435/172","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"1323 - 2025 Tech Binder","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":20681,"username":"Zaque","name":"Zach Hoegberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zaque/{size}/257827_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/recommendations-for-reliable-and-affordable-led-strips/505977/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3731479,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-05T01:59:38.227Z","cooked":"

I haven‚Äôt used them on a bot yet, but I‚Äôve done several other projects with CoB (flexible chip on board) both no-name Aliexpress specials and semi-brand name. They‚Äôve all been fine.

BTF Lighting is a fairly reputable brand name. QuinLED probably puts more care into their product, targeting a little more high-end, but as a result frequently has delays and out-of-stocks. BTF (and random Aliexpress seller #78) are basically never out of stock.

NB: many of the strips above 5V are multi-LED. They are addressable, but only in groups of 3 [12V] or 6 [24V] or so. That still works fine for a robot, but isn‚Äôt quite as smooth as a 5V LED that is controlling on a per-LED basis.

BTF sells direct, on Amazon, and on Ali.

Thank you all for all of the recommendations, I want to include the answer I received from 254 (thank you!)

Team 254 Presents: 2025 UNDERTOW - Technical Binder, Code, Q&A Technical Discussion
It‚Äôs an RGBIC COB Led strip we bought off of Amazon. This is the specific one we have.

Just another datapoint. LumynLabs sells colored LED strips for reasonably cheap that you can consider.

Lumyn Labs

LED Strip

This high-quality LED strip connects to your ConnectorX's LED port(s) via its JST-SM Male connector, ensuring easy installation and a reliable connection.

Price: USD 30.00

They also sell a LED controller and already have a vendordep so its pretty easy to use.

Lumyn Labs

ConnectorX Animate

ConnectorX Animate is all about LEDs! It can handle hundreds of LEDs with a total of four channels and built-in power conversion circuit

Price: USD 74.99

DeepCool EA080 ARGB strips, Diffused lighting, Flexible, Two 400mm strips, Transparent Mounting Clips, 3M adhesive strips

Price: CAD 29.99

I use these DeepCool EA080 ARGB strips for testing. They are built like a beast. I accidently connect they wrong (reverse polority and DI to VCC) more than couple time and they are still going.
